citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The IACUC has completed facility reviews and inspections in October 2023 and April 2024, however reports of its findings
have not been updated and sent to the Institutional Official (IO) at least every 6 months. AWA regulations require that
reports to the IO are reviewed, approved by the IACUC and then submitted to the IO at least every 6 months. Preparing
and submitting program review and facility inspection reports to the IO at least every 6 months helps keep the IO updated
on the program and facility needs for ensuring animal welfare so that these needs can be met by the institution.
***Correct by 9/14/2024

Some areas in enclosures were observed to have areas needing maintenance to prevent risk of injury:
-Four enclosures in the gilt barn has had divider panels removed to provide more space but the end of bolts that secured
them about 5/8 inches in diameter and at least 2 inches long remained in areas that pigs could contact them.
-Two enclosures had areas on the front where panels can attach/detach for (space configuring) that had rounded edges
that were rough to the touch.
-In the quarantine building two ends of larger bolts (about 3/4 in diameter) stuck out about 1.5 inches into a stall doorway
that pigs walk in and out of and two blue panel posts had square metal corners sticking out (about elbow to shoulder
height for the pigs) that could be edges that pigs could bump or get pushed into by other pigs.
-In the gestation housing, an enclosure in the far back right (with your back to the entry door) had a maintenance opening
on the floor. The area was partially blocked off with a stall panel, however a hole in the floor about 4 inches wide that
could be stepped in by the pig housed there. Note: The facility moved this pig to another enclosure prior to the exit
interview.
Rough edges, bolt ends and metal corners, and holes in the floor could cause injury to animals. Ensure that enclosures
are maintained in a manner that protects and prevents pigs from possible injury.
***Correct by 8/29/2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.31(c)(3) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
The IACUC has completed facility reviews and inspections in October 2023 and April 2024, however reports of its findings 
have not been updated and sent to the Institutional Official (IO) at least every 6 months. AWA regulations require that 
reports to the IO are reviewed, approved by the IACUC and then submitted to the IO at least every 6 months. Preparing 
and submitting program review and facility inspection reports to the IO at least every 6 months helps keep the IO updated 
on the program and facility needs for ensuring animal welfare so that these needs can be met by the institution. 
***Correct by 9/14/2024 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Some areas in enclosures were observed to have areas needing maintenance to prevent risk of injury:  
-Four enclosures in the gilt barn has had divider panels removed to provide more space but the end of bolts that secured 
them about 5/8 inches in diameter and at least 2 inches long remained in areas that pigs could contact them.  
-Two enclosures had areas on the front where panels can attach/detach for (space configuring) that had rounded edges 
that were rough to the touch. 
-In the quarantine building two ends of larger bolts (about 3/4 in diameter) stuck out about 1.5 inches into a stall doorway 
that pigs walk in and out of and two blue panel posts had square metal corners sticking out (about elbow to shoulder 
height for the pigs) that could be edges that pigs could bump or get pushed into by other pigs. 
-In the gestation housing, an enclosure in the far back right (with your back to the entry door) had a maintenance opening 
on the floor. The area was partially blocked off with a stall panel, however a hole in the floor about 4 inches wide that 
could be stepped in by the pig housed there. Note: The facility moved this pig to another enclosure prior to the exit 
interview.  
 
Rough edges, bolt ends and metal corners, and holes in the floor could cause injury to animals. Ensure that enclosures 
are maintained in a manner that protects and prevents pigs from possible injury.  
***Correct by 8/29/2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
